p.b: This page is provisional. It will be updated in due time.

There can be last minute changes in the timetable that do not show on this page. Please always check the official times here:
https://cloud.timeedit.net/lu/web/lth1/ri1Q5006.html

ul.li: Typically, each assignment is done by a group of two students. The programming results of it are shown to the instructor who validates it during a laboratory session. You can register to a laboratory group here: https://sam.cs.lth.se/LabsSelectSession?occasionId=594.

After the lab, each and every student writes a report of one to two pages to describe how s/he carried out the assignment, her/his results, and gives a conclusion. You need both to validate your program and hand in a short report to complete your assignment. You must use overleaf to write this report.
Attendance to the laboratory sessions is compulsory. If you are unable to attend, you must report it to your instructor.

We will use Python and scikit-learn in the assignments. The laboratory session of week 1 (lab 0) is intended to review some basic features of Python as well as scikit-learn.
Group 1, September 3, 2019, 08:15 to 10:00, in the Alpha room, group 2, September 3, 2019, 10:15 to 12:00, in the Alpha room, group 3/4, September 3, 2019, 13:15 to 15:00, in the Alpha and Beta rooms, group 5, September 4, 2019, 13:15 to 15:00, in the Falk room, group 6, September 4, 2019, 15:15 to 17:00, in the Falk room.
Anaconda and Pycharm are the recommended programming environments. Both are free.

Lab zero: In this lab, we will review Python and scikit-learn. Attending this lab is not compulsory, but you need to run the spell checker by Peter Norvig to make sure you understand Python. You also have to hand in a short individual report describing the program. The report length should be of one to two pages.

First assignment: Building an inverted index
September 10 and 11, 2019.

Second assignment: Language models
September 17 and 18, 2019.

Third assignment: Extracting noun groups using machine learning techniques (statistical chunking)
September 24 and 25, 2019.

Fourth assignment: Extraction of subject—verb—object triples
October 1st and 2nd, 2019.

Fifth assignment: Dependency parsing
October 8 and 9, 2019.

Sixth assignment: Dependency parsing using machine learning techniques (statistical parsing)
October 15 and 16, 2019.
